text:
I think you've nailed it here. I'm passionate about this and love white space. My most frequent feedback to new writers is exactly this.

Have a read of #4 - #7 in my guest post guidelines: <https://medium.com/the-message-io-dispatch/guest-post-guidelines-for-dispatch-57688123df62>

attachments.fallback: Medium: Guest Post Guidelines for Dispatch
attachments.text: If you’d like to write for Mio’s publication, Dispatch, we’ve compiled our guest post guidelines below.
attachments.title: Guest Post Guidelines for Dispatch

elements.text:
I think you've nailed it here. I'm passionate about this and love white space. My most frequent feedback to new writers is exactly this.

Have a read of #4 - #7 in my guest post guidelines:

text: Aside from everything else you mentioned, I try to add tables as well, wherever possible. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Aside from everything else you mentioned, I try to add tables as well, wherever possible.

text: Add meaningful images - so make sure the main point(a) from each section can be found in a visual format too.

elements.text: Add meaningful images - so make sure the main point(a) from each section can be found in a visual format too.

text: Adding infographics and also outsourced quotes can adorn your content. As adding images gives that small break to the reader.

elements.text: Adding infographics and also outsourced quotes can adorn your content. As adding images gives that small break to the reader.

text: <@U02GYR8TM96> <@U02HD0L8HAP> Do you charge extra for the images and infographics?

elements.text: Do you charge extra for the images and infographics?

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?
I don't create the graphics, they do but I leave clear instructions for them to create it.

elements.text: I don't create the graphics, they do but I leave clear instructions for them to create it.

text: If they're not provided, then yes. I'll usually charge a multiple (2-5x) of what it cost me to hire someone on Fiverr/Upwork to do it.

elements.text: If they're not provided, then yes. I'll usually charge a multiple (2-5x) of what it cost me to hire someone on Fiverr/Upwork to do it.

text: Thank you :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Thank you

text: I'd like to know more about this project. Could you send me more info/details in a DM? Thanks

elements.text: I'd like to know more about this project. Could you send me more info/details in a DM? Thanks

text: One more thing to add to the above: Answer the main question(s) asked within the article (maybe in the headers) with a direct, hopefully short, one-sentence answer. That way, readers could just read that and draw value from the piece without having to go through all the details to find for what they're looking for. Hope that helps! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: One more thing to add to the above: Answer the main question(s) asked within the article (maybe in the headers) with a direct, hopefully short, one-sentence answer. That way, readers could just read that and draw value from the piece without having to go through all the details to find for what they're looking for. Hope that helps!

Sometimes I'll even use a light highlight as a kind of SUPERBOLD, but only sparingly

text: We may not think about it in regards to scannability, but using parallel structure in headers is another good tip. When headers follow the same grammatical pattern (such as all starting with a verb), it’s easier to tell at a glance what section will be most relevant. And I’m a big proponent of pull quotes as well.

elements.text: We may not think about it in regards to scannability, but using parallel structure in headers is another good tip. When headers follow the same grammatical pattern (such as all starting with a verb), it’s easier to tell at a glance what section will be most relevant. And I’m a big proponent of pull quotes as well.

text: Hey freelance folks. I need to estimate hours for a video project. It requires a freelancer to write 5 min scripts for 6 different videos. Does anyone have an average breakdown for how they'd look at this project? No research required and each script will be about 750 words. I want to make sure I'm paying our freelancer fairly and also giving them a fair timeframe

text:
Hey everyone:wave::skin-tone-5:

I'm currently considering reviewing my payment terms with a new client. We had a short chat yesterday on Zoom and we agreed to a paid test project first to see if we're a great fit. Before, I usually work on a project and get 100% payment once I'm done. However, I plan to at least get 50% upfront before I start working.

Curious to know which payment terms have the best work for you as a freelancer? Has any client pushed back when you ask for part payment before you start a project?

Would love to hear from you:slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hey everyone

I'm currently considering reviewing my payment terms with a new client. We had a short chat yesterday on Zoom and we agreed to a paid test project first to see if we're a great fit. Before, I usually work on a project and get 100% payment once I'm done. However, I plan to at least get 50% upfront before I start working.

Curious to know which payment terms have the best work for you as a freelancer? Has any client pushed back when you ask for part payment before you start a project?

Would love to hear from you

text:
Following :slightly_smiling_face:
I've never actually asked for upfront payment, I'm like you Femi and finish the job before invoicing. If its a regular gig like a few blog posts per month, I'll invoice on the 1st for the previous months work

text: I just switched to asking for 1/3 of the cost upfront on one-off projects. I haven't had any push back. They'd get the same (or more) from an agency. I think it's pretty customary. It also gives them some skin in the game to make sure you're both happy with the end product.

elements.text: I just switched to asking for 1/3 of the cost upfront on one-off projects. I haven't had any push back. They'd get the same (or more) from an agency. I think it's pretty customary. It also gives them some skin in the game to make sure you're both happy with the end product.
